title: 114_hr1396
content: The Act may be cited as the "Federal Communications Commission Collaboration Act of 2015". Congress acknowledges that the Federal Communications Commission has faced challenges in conducting substantive discussions and decision-making due to the limitations of section 552b of title 5, United States Code. The purpose of creating a multimember agency is to benefit from diverse perspectives and expertise in decision-making processes. Commissioners have struggled with inefficient communication methods, hindering effective collaboration. The Federal Communications Commission has faced challenges in conducting substantive discussions and decision-making due to inefficient communication methods. This includes written messages, staff communications, and restricted meetings among Commissioners. The lack of collegiality and cooperation has hindered progress on regulatory matters, potentially impacting innovation and private investment in the domestic communications industry. To address these issues, the Commission must work collaboratively and efficiently to expand broadband Internet access to meet the needs of all people in the United States. SEC. 3. NONPUBLIC COLLABORATIVE DISCUSSIONS OF THE FEDERAL COMMUNICATIONS COMMISSION. Section 4 of the Communications Act of 1934 is amended to allow a bipartisan majority of Commissioners to hold closed meetings to discuss official business, as long as no vote or agency action is taken, and only specific individuals are present. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to allow closed meetings for Commissioners to discuss official business with specific individuals present. The Commission must disclose attendees and a summary of discussions within 2 business days, while still preserving open meeting requirements for agency action. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to allow closed meetings for Commissioners to discuss official business with specific individuals present. The applicability of section 552b of title 5, United States Code, is defined for meetings of Commissioners, ensuring a bipartisan majority is present. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to allow closed meetings for Commissioners to discuss official business with specific individuals present, ensuring a bipartisan majority is present, including unaffiliated Commissioners.
